segment.source: Network deployment to Surface devices can pose some unique challenges for system administrators.
segment.target: Network deployment to Surface devices can pose some unique challenges for system administrators.

segment.source: Due to the lack of a native wired Ethernet adapter, administrators must provide connectivity through a removable Ethernet adapter.
segment.target: Due to the lack of a native wired Ethernet adapter, administrators must provide connectivity through a removable Ethernet adapter.

segment.source: Select an Ethernet adapter for Surface devices
segment.target: Select an Ethernet adapter for Surface devices

segment.source: Before you can address the concerns of how you will boot to your deployment environment or how devices will be recognized by your deployment solution, you have to use a wired network adapter.
segment.target: Before you can address the concerns of how you will boot to your deployment environment or how devices will be recognized by your deployment solution, you have to use a wired network adapter.

segment.source: The primary concern when selecting an Ethernet adapter is how that adapter will boot your Surface device from the network.
segment.target: The primary concern when selecting an Ethernet adapter is how that adapter will boot your Surface device from the network.

segment.source: If you are pre-staging clients with Windows Deployment Services (WDS) or if you are using System Center Configuration Manager, you may also want to consider whether the removable Ethernet adapters will be dedicated to a specific Surface device or shared among multiple devices.
segment.target: If you are pre-staging clients with Windows Deployment Services (WDS) or if you are using System Center Configuration Manager, you may also want to consider whether the removable Ethernet adapters will be dedicated to a specific Surface device or shared among multiple devices.

segment.source: See the Manage MAC addresses with removable Ethernet adapters section of this article for more information on potential conflicts with shared adapters.
segment.target: See the Manage MAC addresses with removable Ethernet adapters section of this article for more information on potential conflicts with shared adapters.

segment.source: Booting from the network (PXE boot) is only supported when you use an Ethernet adapter or docking station from Microsoft.
segment.target: Booting from the network (PXE boot) is only supported when you use an Ethernet adapter or docking station from Microsoft.

segment.source: To boot from the network, the chipset in the Ethernet adapter or dock must be detected and configured as a boot device in the firmware of the Surface device.
segment.target: To boot from the network, the chipset in the Ethernet adapter or dock must be detected and configured as a boot device in the firmware of the Surface device.

segment.source: Microsoft Ethernet adapters, such as the Surface Ethernet Adapter and the Surface Dock use a chipset that is compatible with the Surface firmware.
segment.target: Microsoft Ethernet adapters, such as the Surface Ethernet Adapter and the Surface Dock use a chipset that is compatible with the Surface firmware.

segment.source: Third-party Ethernet adapters are also supported for network deployment, although they do not support PXE boot.
segment.target: Third-party Ethernet adapters are also supported for network deployment, although they do not support PXE boot.

segment.source: To use a third-party Ethernet adapter, you must load the drivers into the deployment boot image and you must launch that boot image from a separate storage device, such as a USB stick.
segment.target: To use a third-party Ethernet adapter, you must load the drivers into the deployment boot image and you must launch that boot image from a separate storage device, such as a USB stick.

segment.source: Boot Surface devices from the network
segment.target: Boot Surface devices from the network

segment.source: To boot from the network or a connected USB stick, you must instruct the Surface device to boot from an alternate boot device.
segment.target: To boot from the network or a connected USB stick, you must instruct the Surface device to boot from an alternate boot device.

segment.source: You can alter the boot order in the system firmware to prioritize USB boot devices, or you can instruct it to boot from an alternate boot device during the boot up process.
segment.target: You can alter the boot order in the system firmware to prioritize USB boot devices, or you can instruct it to boot from an alternate boot device during the boot up process.

segment.source: To boot a Surface device from an alternative boot device, follow these steps:
segment.target: To boot a Surface device from an alternative boot device, follow these steps:

segment.source: Ensure the Surface device is powered off.
segment.target: Ensure the Surface device is powered off.

segment.source: Press and hold the Volume Down button.
segment.target: Press and hold the Volume Down button.

segment.source: Press and release the Power button.
segment.target: Press and release the Power button.

segment.source: After the system begins to boot from the USB stick or Ethernet adapter, release the Volume Down button.
segment.target: After the system begins to boot from the USB stick or Ethernet adapter, release the Volume Down button.

segment.source: Note: In addition to an Ethernet adapter, a keyboard must also be connected to the Surface device to enter the preinstallation environment and navigate the deployment wizard.
segment.target: Note: In addition to an Ethernet adapter, a keyboard must also be connected to the Surface device to enter the preinstallation environment and navigate the deployment wizard.

segment.source: To support booting from the network in a Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE), such as is used in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit and Configuration Manager, you must add drivers for the Ethernet adapter to WinPE.
segment.target: To support booting from the network in a Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE), such as is used in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit and Configuration Manager, you must add drivers for the Ethernet adapter to WinPE.

segment.source: You can download the drivers for Surface Ethernet adapters from the Microsoft Download Center page for your specific device.
segment.target: You can download the drivers for Surface Ethernet adapters from the Microsoft Download Center page for your specific device.

segment.source: For a list of the available downloads for Surface devices, see Download the latest firmware and drivers for Surface devices.

segment.source: Manage MAC addresses with removable Ethernet adapters
segment.target: Manage MAC addresses with removable Ethernet adapters

segment.source: Another consideration for administrators performing Windows deployment over the network is how you will identify computers when you use the same Ethernet adapter to deploy to more than one computer.
segment.target: Another consideration for administrators performing Windows deployment over the network is how you will identify computers when you use the same Ethernet adapter to deploy to more than one computer.

segment.source: A common identifier used by deployment technologies is the Media Access Control (MAC) address that is associated with each Ethernet adapter.
segment.target: A common identifier used by deployment technologies is the Media Access Control (MAC) address that is associated with each Ethernet adapter.

segment.source: However, when you use the same Ethernet adapter to deploy to multiple computers, you cannot use a deployment technology that inspects MAC addresses because there is no way to differentiate the MAC address of the removable adapter when used on the different computers.
segment.target: However, when you use the same Ethernet adapter to deploy to multiple computers, you cannot use a deployment technology that inspects MAC addresses because there is no way to differentiate the MAC address of the removable adapter when used on the different computers.

segment.source: The simplest solution to avoid MAC address conflicts is to provide a dedicated removable Ethernet adapter for each Surface device.
segment.target: The simplest solution to avoid MAC address conflicts is to provide a dedicated removable Ethernet adapter for each Surface device.

segment.source: This can make sense in many scenarios where the Ethernet adapter or the additional functionality of the docking station will be used regularly.
segment.target: This can make sense in many scenarios where the Ethernet adapter or the additional functionality of the docking station will be used regularly.

segment.source: However, not all scenarios call for the additional connectivity of a docking station or support for wired networks.
segment.target: However, not all scenarios call for the additional connectivity of a docking station or support for wired networks.

segment.source: Another potential solution to avoid conflict when adapters are shared is to use the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) to perform deployment to Surface devices.
segment.target: Another potential solution to avoid conflict when adapters are shared is to use the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) to perform deployment to Surface devices.

segment.source: MDT does not use the MAC address to identify individual computers and thus is not subject to this limitation.
segment.target: MDT does not use the MAC address to identify individual computers and thus is not subject to this limitation.

segment.source: However, MDT does use Windows Deployment Services to provide PXE boot functionality, and is subject to the limitations regarding pre-staged clients which is covered later in this section.
segment.target: However, MDT does use Windows Deployment Services to provide PXE boot functionality, and is subject to the limitations regarding pre-staged clients which is covered later in this section.

segment.source: When you use a shared adapter for deployment, the solution for affected deployment technologies is to use another means to identify unique systems.
segment.target: When you use a shared adapter for deployment, the solution for affected deployment technologies is to use another means to identify unique systems.

segment.source: For Configuration Manager and WDS, both of which can be affected by this issue, the solution is to use the System Universal Unique Identifier (System UUID) that is embedded in the computer firmware by the computer manufacturer.
segment.target: For Configuration Manager and WDS, both of which can be affected by this issue, the solution is to use the System Universal Unique Identifier (System UUID) that is embedded in the computer firmware by the computer manufacturer.

segment.source: For Surface devices, you can see this entry in the computer firmware under Device Information.
segment.target: For Surface devices, you can see this entry in the computer firmware under Device Information.

segment.source: To access the firmware of a Surface device, follow these steps:
segment.target: To access the firmware of a Surface device, follow these steps:

segment.source: Ensure the Surface device is powered off.
segment.target: Ensure the Surface device is powered off.

segment.source: Press and hold the Volume Up button.
segment.target: Press and hold the Volume Up button.

segment.source: Press and release the Power button.
segment.target: Press and release the Power button.

segment.source: After the device begins to boot, release the Volume Up button.
segment.target: After the device begins to boot, release the Volume Up button.

segment.source: When deploying with WDS, the MAC address is only used to identify a computer when the deployment server is configured to respond only to known, pre-staged clients.
segment.target: When deploying with WDS, the MAC address is only used to identify a computer when the deployment server is configured to respond only to known, pre-staged clients.

segment.source: When pre-staging a client, an administrator creates a computer account in Active Directory and defines that computer by the MAC address or the System UUID.
segment.target: When pre-staging a client, an administrator creates a computer account in Active Directory and defines that computer by the MAC address or the System UUID.

segment.source: To avoid the identity conflicts caused by shared Ethernet adapters, you should use System UUID to define pre-staged clients.
segment.target: To avoid the identity conflicts caused by shared Ethernet adapters, you should use System UUID to define pre-staged clients.

segment.source: Alternatively, you can configure WDS to respond to unknown clients that do not require definition by either MAC address or System UUID by selecting the Respond to all client computers (known and unknown) option on the PXE Response tab in Windows Deployment Server Properties.
segment.target: Alternatively, you can configure WDS to respond to unknown clients that do not require definition by either MAC address or System UUID by selecting the Respond to all client computers (known and unknown) option on the PXE Response tab in Windows Deployment Server Properties.

segment.source: The potential for conflicts with shared Ethernet adapters is much higher with Configuration Manager.
segment.target: The potential for conflicts with shared Ethernet adapters is much higher with Configuration Manager.

segment.source: Where WDS only uses MAC addresses to define individual systems when configured to do so, Configuration Manager uses the MAC address to define individual systems whenever performing a deployment to new or unknown computers.
segment.target: Where WDS only uses MAC addresses to define individual systems when configured to do so, Configuration Manager uses the MAC address to define individual systems whenever performing a deployment to new or unknown computers.

segment.source: This can result in improperly configured devices or even the inability to deploy more than one system with a shared Ethernet adapter.
segment.target: This can result in improperly configured devices or even the inability to deploy more than one system with a shared Ethernet adapter.

segment.source: There are several potential solutions for this situation that are described in detail in the How to Use The Same External Ethernet Adapter For Multiple SCCM OSD blog post on the Ask Premier Field Engineering (PFE) Platforms TechNet blog.
segment.target: There are several potential solutions for this situation that are described in detail in the How to Use The Same External Ethernet Adapter For Multiple SCCM OSD blog post on the Ask Premier Field Engineering (PFE) Platforms TechNet blog.
